Influenza A viruses (IAVs) can infect many animal species including humans and pigs, and are considered a major public health risk because zoonotic infections can cause human pandemics
1 . Swine are considered a dominant species for global IAV delivery
2 and pig movements within and between countries contribute to the increased diversity of swine IAVs
3â€“ 5 . However, the epidemiology, diversity and molecular evolution of IAVs during natural infection of pigs are not clearly understood. Understanding the mechanisms that allow IAVs to evolve and persist in swine populations is crucial to design health interventions that minimize viral transmission between pigs and from pigs to people.
